Complex potential and bottomonium suppression at LHC energy
Uttam Kakade, * Binoy Krishna Patra † and Lata Thakur ‡
Department of Physics, Indian Institute of Technology Roorkee, 247 667, India
* usk11dph@iitr.ac.in
† binoyfph@iitr.ac.in
‡ lata1dph@iitr.ac.in
Received 29 October 2014
Revised 16 January 2015
Accepted 22 January 2015
Published 18 March 2015
We have studied the thermal suppression of the bottomonium states in relativistic heavy-
ion collision at LHC energies as function of centrality, rapidity, transverse momentum.
First, we address the effects of the nonperturbative confining force and the momentum
anisotropy together on heavy quark potential at finite temperature, which are resolved
by correcting both the perturbative and nonperturbative terms of the potential at T = 0
in a weakly-anisotropic medium, not its perturbative term alone as usually done in the
literature. Second, we model the expansion of medium by the Bjorken hydrodynamics in
the presence of both shear and bulk viscosity, followed by an additional pre-equilibrium
anisotropic evolution. Finally, we couple them together to quantify the yields of bottomo-
nium production in nucleus–nucleus collisions at LHC energies and found a better agree-
ment with the CMS data. Our estimate of the inclusive Υ(1S) production indirectly
constrains both the uncertainties in isotropization time and the shear-to-entropy den-
sity ratio and favors the values as 0.3 fm/c and 0.3 (perturbative result), respectively.
Keywords: Bottomonium states; nonperturbative effects; thermal suppression; aniso-
tropy; pre-equilibrium; isotropization; viscous forces.
PACS numbers: 12.39.−x, 11.10.St, 12.38.Mh, 12.39.Pn, 12.39.Hg, 12.38.Gc

The experimental heavy ion programs at SPS, RHIC and LHC open up an window
into the phase diagram of QCD in the region of small baryon density. Lattice calcula-
tions
1 predict a crossover transition for temperatures ranging from 150 to 200 MeV.
From experimental point of view, the properties of the medium can be characterized
by either through its bulk properties or the hard probes. Heavy quarkonium has
been one of the most actively investigated hard probes in this connection. Matsui
and Satz
2 first proposed the idea of Debye screening of the potential between a
heavy quark and a heavy antiquark, which causes the suppression of the yields of

3–5 Nowadays, the dissociation
mechanism identified is known as Landau-damping,
6 when a light parton of the
medium (either gluon or quark) scatters off the bound state by exchanging gluons
and dissociates it into an unbound color octet. The current consensus is that the
experimental results cannot be explained by the cold nuclear matter effects alone,
therefore the effects of hot nuclear matter are still under investigation. Moreover
the LHC results have opened up the possibility of the cleaner bottomonium probe
with the availability of quality data on the Υ resonances,
4 which is the central
theme of our work.
A large number of studies on the in-medium dynamics of the Q ¯

however not established. However, lattice calculations of free energies and other
quantities
8,9 obtained from the correlation functions of Polyakov loop are often
taken as input for the potential. Although these quantities have been thought to
be related to the color-singlet and color-octet heavy quark potentials at finite tem-
perature
9,10 a precise answer is still missing.

perature has been studied by taking advantage of the nonrelativistic and thermal
energy scales that characterize the system. There are different scales in the heavy
quark bound state problem related to the heavy quark mass m Q , the exchange
of momentum ∼ m Q v Q and the binding energy ∼ m Q v

one assumes ideal hydrodynamical evolution. However, the separation of thermal
scales in EFT is not evident and one needs lattice techniques to test the approach,
where the dissociation of the quarkonium states can be studied even without the
potential models rather the physics of a given quarkonium state is encoded in its
spectral function in terms of the Euclidean meson correlation functions.
26–33 How-
ever, the reconstruction of the spectral function from the lattice meson correlators
turns out to be very difficult. At finite temperature the situation becomes worse
because the temporal extent is decreasing and particularly, for the bottomonium
states, it becomes worst, thus inadvertently supports the use of potential models
at finite temperature to complement the lattice studies.
The above-mentioned discussion of quarkonium at finite temperature becomes
complicated in nucleus–nucleus collisions. The heavy quark (Q ¯
Q) pairs are pro-
duced in heavy ion collisions on a very short time-scale (∼ 1/2m Q ). The initial
state effects on the parton densities (shadowing),
34 the initial state energy loss,
35
the final state absorption on nucleons
34,36 etc. could affect the production mech-
anism intimately. The shadowing and absorption are important at mid rapidity
whereas the (initial-state) energy loss and intrinsic heavy flavor are important at
forward rapidity. As the time elapsed, the resonances are formed over a formation
time, τ F and traverses the plasma and then the hadronic matter before leaving
the interacting system to be decayed into a dilepton. By the time the resonance is
formed, either the screening of the color force
2 or an energetic gluon,
37–40 even a
comoving hadron
41 could dissociate the resonance(s). Thus, a study of quarkonium
production in nuclear collisions is poised to provide a wealth of information about
the evolution of the plasma and the in-medium properties of quarkonia states. At
SPS and RHIC, most of the interests were focused on the suppression of c¯ c bound
states
2,7,42–47 but several observations are yet to be understood namely the suppres-
sion of ψ(1S) does not increase from SPS to RHIC, even though the center-of-mass
energy is increased by 15 times. The heavy-ion program at the LHC may resolve
those puzzles because the beam energy and luminosity are increased by 10 times
of that of the RHIC. That is why the interest may be shifted to the bottomonium
states at the LHC energy due to the following reasons: (i) The initial state effects
are much smaller than the charmonium production. (ii) The competition due to the
recombination is unlikely. (iii) The bottomonium states can be dealt efficiently by
the potential approach. (iv) Although the Υ states have diverse binding energies
their similar decay kinematics and production mechanisms enable to measure their
relative suppression unambiguously.
The works described above were limited to an isotropic medium but the system
produced in relativistic heavy-ion collision may not be homogeneous and isotropic
because at the early stages of the collision, the asymptotic weak-coupling enhances
the longitudinal expansion substantially than the radial expansion. There have been
significant advances in the dynamical models used to simulate plasma evolution with

48–53 In recent years, the effects of anisotropy
on the quarkonia states have been extensively investigated
54–57 by the leading-
anisotropic correction to the perturbative term of the potential alone. Although
the direct lattice QCD based determinations of the potential have progressed a lot,
still a model potential for the phenomenological descriptions of heavy quarkonium
suppression would indeed be quite useful.
The aforesaid works
54–57 assumed only a screened Coulomb potential above
the critical temperature (T c ) because the linear/string term was assumed to be
zero. However, the string tension does not vanish abruptly at the deconfinement
temperature,
58–61 so one should study its effect on heavy quark potential even
above T c . This issue usually overlooked in the literature was certainly worth of
investigation. Therefore, we had recently derived the medium modifications to both
perturbative and nonperturbative terms of the Q ¯
Q potential
62–64 in the presence
of a not necessarily isotropic QCD medium. We found that the inclusion of the
confining string term makes both the real and imaginary parts of the potential
more stronger, compared to the medium correction of the perturbative term of the
potential alone.
63,64 Moreover, the presence of the anisotropy makes the real-part
of the potential stronger but the imaginary-part becomes leaner and overall the
anisotropy makes the quarkonia to dissociate at higher temperatures, compared to
the isotropic medium.
Recently the quarkonium suppression in nucleus–nucleus collisions has been
studied
65 by employing the potentials
54,55,57 with the medium modifications of
the perturbative term (Coulomb) of the potential alone in an anisotropic medium.
In the present work, we have employed the potential in Ref. 63 in anisotropic
medium, where medium modifications to both perturbative and nonperturbative
(string) terms are taken into account. Thereafter we have numerically obtained the
dissociation temperatures of the ground and the excited states of the Υ family. We
have found that the quarkonium states are now dissociated at higher temperatures
compared to the medium-consideration of the Coulomb term alone, which may
have an impact on bottomonium suppression. With these understandings about the
quarkonia states, we aim to study the dynamical suppression of the bottomonium
states at the LHC and observed that the local equilibrium hydrodynamic regime
alone may not be sufficient to suppress the bottomonium states adequately and
some additional pre-equilibrium time zone of plasma evolution may be needed. The
unique features of the bottomonium ground (1S) state, namely the tiny formation
time (≤ isotropization time) and the large binding energy, facilitate to probe both
the (pre-equilibrium) era prior to the isotropization time and the shear viscosity-
to-the entropy density ratio.

rections to the retarded, advanced and symmetric gluon self-energies and the cor-
responding propagators and then obtained the real and imaginary parts of the
potential. We then employ the complex potential to obtain the real and imaginary

2. Bottomonium in Anisotropic Medium
An interesting property at the initial phase of the QGP is the presence of the
momentum anisotropy.
66–68 It is therefore worthwhile to consider the properties of
quarkonia such as the binding energy, decay width in such a system. The calculation

13,55,69 by the leading
anisotropic corrections to the perturbative term of the potential alone and coupled
with the dynamical evolution of the anisotropic plasma. We now continue with
the above works to derive the potential at finite temperature keeping both the
perturbative and nonperturbative terms via the Keyldesh presentation in real-time
formalism.

one is related to the time scale of thermalization, the second one is the formation

Our calculation assumes that the system produced in relativistic heavy-ion colli-
sion expands successively though pre-equilibrium and equilibrium evolutions, which
follow slower and faster cooling rate, respectively. Since the physics of isotropiza-
tion/equilibration is yet to understand theoretically, so the duration of the pre-
equilibrium era is uncertain. Hence we vary the isotropization time scale (τ iso ) and
constrain it by the bottomonium suppression observed at LHC, as follows: The
dynamical suppression for any state starts only after its formation, i.e. τ ≥ τ F and
continues as long as the energy density of the system is greater than the screening
energy density, i.e. ǫ ≥ ǫ s . Since the duration of screening times depends especially
on the cooling rate (discussed in the first paragraph of this section), so the expan-
sion rates and the durations of the pre-equilibrium and equilibrium evolutions offer
a rich structure to the suppression pattern. For a given state if τ F ≥ τ iso then state
is suppressed dynamically through the equilibrium hydrodynamics only whereas if
τ F < τ iso then state is suppressed through the pre-equilibrium evolution till τ iso
and then through the equilibrium hydrodynamics. Therefore for τ iso = 0.2 fm/c,
all the bottomonium states (with τ F , given in Table 1) are suppressed through
the equilibrium regime, and hence shows less inclusive suppression, compared to
higher τ iso . For example, for τ iso = 0.3 fm/c, only the Υ(1S) state passes through
both pre-equilibrium and equilibrium evolutions whereas the excited states (Υ(2S),
Υ(3S) etc.) pass through the equilibrium regime only. So the excited states are not
affected by the pre-equilibrium evolution. Moreover since the time spent by Υ(1S)
in the pre-equilibrium regime is very small and the difference in the cooling rates
of two regimes are not large in the initial stage of evolution, so the effect of varying
τ iso (from 0.2–1 fm/c) on the Υ(1S) suppression is not drastic. This is also seen in
Fig. 9(a).

suitable handle to decipher the time scales associated with the equilibration.
4. Conclusions
In conclusion, we have studied the sequential suppression for Υ(1S) and Υ(2S)
states at the LHC energy in a longitudinally expanding partonic system, which
undergone the successive pre-equilibrium and equilibrium phases in the presence
of dissipative forces. Quarkonium suppression in nucleus–nucleus collisions com-
pared to p–p collisions couples the in-medium properties of the quarkonium states
with the dynamics of the expanding medium. In this work, we obtained the dis-
sociation temperatures of the quarkonium states by correcting both the perturba-
tive and nonperturbative terms in Q ¯
Q potential in (an)isotropic medium through
the HTL resummed perturbation. We then modeled the pre-equilibrium evolution
as anisotropic fluid via the time-dependent anisotropic parameter, ξ(τ ) and hard
momentum scale, P hard (τ ) while the equilibrium era is governed by the second-order
dissipative hydrodynamics in (1 + 1) Bjorken boost-invariant model and coupled
them together to estimate the sequential suppression. The expansion in equilib-
rium hydrodynamics is controlled by the speed of sound c
2
s , which could be further
handled by the lattice QCD equation of state, the shear (η) and bulk (ζ) viscous
forces, etc.

ing rate and thus causes more suppression to the ground state, however, the bulk
